questions.question: A company forecasted demand of 1,000 units, but actual customer orders were 1,200. What is this difference called?
questions.explanation: Forecast error is the difference between actual demand and forecasted demand. Managing forecast error is critical for planning safety stock and improving forecast accuracy.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand Management (Forecasting and Forecast Error, pp. 2.35–2.40)

questions.question: Which inventory is held to protect against uncertainty in demand or supply?
questions.explanation: Safety stock acts as a buffer against variations in demand or supply lead time. It reduces the risk of stockouts.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Types of Inventory – Safety Stock, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: The primary output of the Master Production Schedule (MPS) is:
questions.explanation: MPS translates the production plan into specific build schedules for end items, balancing demand with available resources.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Master Planning (Purpose and Outputs of MPS, pp. 3.25–3.30)

questions.question: Which technique is used to validate the feasibility of the Master Production Schedule (MPS)?
questions.explanation: RCCP checks whether critical resources (like bottleneck work centers, labor, and key machines) have enough capacity to support the MPS.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Rough-Cut Capacity Planning, pp. 4.10–4.15)

questions.question: The main purpose of Sales and Operations Planning (S&OP) is to:

options.a: Forecast sales at the product level
options.b: Reconcile supply and demand at an aggregate level

questions.explanation: S&OP aligns business strategy, sales forecasts, and operations planning to ensure a feasible, balanced plan that supports financial and operational goals.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Purpose and Benefits, pp. 2.5–2.12)

questions.question: Which type of bill of material (BOM) is used to plan options and variations in a product family?
questions.explanation: A planning BOM is used in forecasting and MPS to plan for product families with many variations.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Bills of Material, pp. 3.20–3.25)

questions.question: Which system uses actual consumption data to trigger replenishment signals?
questions.explanation: Kanban is a pull system where replenishment is triggered by actual consumption rather than forecast.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean and JIT, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which measure reflects the percentage of time a machine is actually producing compared to available time?
questions.explanation: Utilization is the ratio of actual running time to total available time.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Capacity Measurement, pp. 4.25–4.30)

questions.question: In MRP, which file contains information about lead times, lot sizes, and safety stock for each item?
questions.explanation: The item master file includes planning data such as lot sizes, lead times, and safety stock requirements.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Inputs, pp. 3.35–3.40)

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of time fences in MPS?

options.a: To freeze near-term schedules and provide stability

questions.explanation: Time fences prevent unnecessary changes to production schedules close to execution, improving stability.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Master Planning (Time Fences, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which distribution planning technique determines the timing and quantity of stock movements between facilities?
questions.explanation: DRP is the time-phased planning tool for distribution networks, determining when and how much inventory to replenish.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 5 – Distribution (DRP, pp. 5.10–5.15)

questions.question: Which inventory management approach focuses on continuous counting rather than annual physical inventory?
questions.explanation: Cycle counting is a perpetual method to maintain inventory accuracy by checking selected items regularly.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Cycle Counting, pp. 4.35–4.40)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing technique always orders the exact net requirements for each period?
questions.explanation: Lot-for-lot ordering matches order quantity to net requirements for each period, minimizing inventory but increasing order frequency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lot Sizing Techniques, pp. 3.50–3.55)

questions.question: Which measure indicates how much demand can be met from current inventory without replenishment?
questions.explanation: ATP indicates the uncommitted portion of inventory and planned production available to support new customer orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Master Planning (Available-to-Promise, pp. 3.18–3.22)

questions.question: Which document authorizes the release of materials to production?
questions.explanation: A work order authorizes production to start and allows materials to be issued from inventory to the shop floor.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Work Orders, pp. 3.65–3.70)

questions.question: Which planning approach starts at the finished goods level and works backward to determine requirements?
questions.explanation: MRP is a backward-scheduling process that calculates requirements for components based on the MPS.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Logic, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which metric measures how many times inventory is sold and replaced during a given period?
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover is calculated as cost of goods sold divided by average inventory, showing how efficiently inventory is used.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Performance Metrics, pp. 4.45–4.50)

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a routing file?

options.b: To sequence operations and identify resources

questions.explanation: The routing file defines the operations sequence, work centers, and times needed to produce a product.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Routing Data, pp. 3.60–3.65)

questions.question: Which system integrates financial, distribution, and manufacturing data into a single database?
questions.explanation: ERP integrates enterprise-wide processes across finance, manufacturing, and supply chain in a centralized system.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (ERP, pp. 1.40–1.45)

questions.question: Which inventory type results from production faster than customer demand?
questions.explanation: Anticipation inventory is built in advance of predictable demand increases or seasonal fluctuations.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Anticipation Inventory, pp. 4.12–4.15)

questions.question: What is the main purpose of capacity requirements planning (CRP)?

options.c: To plan detailed work center loads

questions.explanation: CRP calculates the load at each work center to ensure capacity matches planned orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Capacity Requirements Planning, pp. 4.20–4.25)

questions.question: Which approach uses ABC classification to determine inventory management effort?
questions.explanation: Cycle counting often uses ABC analysis so high-value (A) items are counted more frequently than low-value items.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Cycle Counting Approaches, pp. 4.35–4.40)

questions.question: Which measure evaluates the ability to deliver customer orders on the promised date?
questions.explanation: On-time delivery measures the percentage of orders delivered as promised, reflecting reliability in scheduling.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 1.25–1.30)

questions.question: What is the main output of material requirements planning (MRP)?
questions.explanation: MRP produces time-phased planned orders for procurement and production to meet dependent demand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Outputs, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which process translates the business plan into a mid-term operational plan?
questions.explanation: S&OP is the cross-functional process for reconciling supply and demand at an aggregate level over the medium term.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Linking Business Plan and Operations, pp. 2.8–2.12)

questions.question: Which concept refers to the longest path through a project schedule?
questions.explanation: Critical path is the sequence of dependent activities with zero slack that determines total project duration.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 5 – Distribution and Logistics (Project Scheduling Concepts, pp. 5.25–5.30)

questions.question: Which lean concept focuses on producing only what is needed when it is needed?
questions.explanation: Pull systems authorize production based on actual consumption, minimizing excess WIP and inventory.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Principles, pp. 3.42–3.48)

questions.question: Which inventory performance measure is defined as the percentage of demand met without backorders?
questions.explanation: Fill rate measures the proportion of demand filled directly from stock, showing customer service effectiveness.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 4.42–4.45)

questions.question: Which type of capacity is based on the maximum output a system can produce under ideal conditions?
questions.explanation: Theoretical capacity is based on maximum output with no downtime or inefficiencies; it is rarely attainable.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Types of Capacity, pp. 4.8–4.12)

questions.question: Which measure indicates how quickly inventory is sold and replenished during a specific period?
questions.explanation: The inventory turnover ratio measures how often inventory is sold and replaced over a given period, reflecting efficiency of stock management.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Performance Metrics, pp. 4.46–4.50)

questions.question: Which document specifies the materials, quantities, and sequence needed to produce an item?
questions.explanation: A Bill of Material (BOM) lists components, subassemblies, and their quantities required to make a finished product.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Bills of Material, pp. 3.20–3.25)

questions.question: Which system balances supply and demand by using time-phased order releases?
questions.explanation: MRP plans time-phased order releases to meet dependent demand while considering lead times and inventory policies.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Logic, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which term describes the alignment of long-term business strategy with operations planning?
questions.explanation: S&OP ensures alignment between long-term strategy, financial goals, and mid-range operations planning.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Strategic Alignment, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which scheduling method aims to synchronize production with the rate of customer demand?
questions.explanation: Takt time scheduling matches production pace to the rate of customer demand, minimizing overproduction.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Concepts, pp. 3.48–3.52)

questions.question: Which concept represents a planned order that has not yet been released?
questions.explanation: Planned order releases are future orders suggested by MRP but not yet released to production or suppliers.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Outputs, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which type of stock is in transit between locations in a supply chain?
questions.explanation: Pipeline inventory represents goods in transit between facilities or supply chain nodes.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Types of Inventory, pp. 4.18–4.22)

questions.question: Which planning level focuses on long-term decisions such as facility location and capacity investment?
questions.explanation: Strategic planning involves long-term capacity, facility, and investment decisions aligning with business goals.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (Planning Hierarchy, pp. 1.15–1.20)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing method balances setup cost and carrying cost by ordering at an economic quantity?
questions.explanation: EOQ minimizes total cost by balancing setup and holding costs.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lot Sizing, pp. 3.50–3.55)

questions.question: Which approach ensures production orders are only released when capacity is available?
questions.explanation: Finite loading schedules orders only when sufficient capacity is available, improving feasibility of plans.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Finite and Infinite Loading, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which scheduling method focuses on completing jobs by their due dates while minimizing lateness?
questions.explanation: The earliest due date rule prioritizes jobs with the earliest deadlines to minimize lateness.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Scheduling Rules, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which manufacturing environment produces standardized products in large volumes with low flexibility?
questions.explanation: MTS environments produce standardized products in anticipation of demand, with low customization.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (Manufacturing Environments, pp. 1.20–1.25)

questions.question: Which Lean concept involves leveling production to reduce variability?
questions.explanation: Heijunka levels production to smooth demand variability and optimize flow.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Tools, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which capacity measure reflects actual demonstrated output over time?
questions.explanation: Demonstrated capacity is based on actual historical output, reflecting realistic performance.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Capacity Measures, pp. 4.12–4.16)

questions.question: Which order policy triggers replenishment only when inventory falls below a set level?
questions.explanation: The reorder point system initiates replenishment when inventory reaches a predetermined level.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Reorder Point Planning, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which process focuses on short-term scheduling and execution on the shop floor?
questions.explanation: Detailed scheduling and planning focuses on shop-floor scheduling, order release, and execution.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Short-term Scheduling, pp. 3.10–3.15)

questions.question: Which customer service measure calculates the portion of demand satisfied directly from stock?
questions.explanation: Fill rate is the percentage of demand that can be met immediately from available inventory.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which tool is used to analyze demand variability by categorizing items based on value and frequency of use?
questions.explanation: ABC classification segments inventory into A, B, and C categories based on value and frequency, guiding control efforts.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (ABC Analysis, pp. 4.28–4.33)

questions.question: Which output of capacity requirements planning (CRP) shows the load versus available capacity at each work center?
questions.explanation: CRP generates load profiles that compare planned workload against available capacity at each work center.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (CRP Outputs, pp. 4.22–4.28)

questions.question: Which lean practice empowers workers to stop production when a defect occurs?
questions.explanation: Jidoka enables workers to stop production when a problem arises, ensuring quality at the source.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Principles, pp. 3.42–3.48)

questions.question: What is meant by "dependent demand" in inventory management?

options.a: Demand for finished goods based on customer orders
options.b: Demand for components or raw materials based on the production schedule

questions.explanation: Dependent demand is demand directly related to the demand for another item, usually components needed to make finished products.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Demand Types, pp. 3.10–3.15)

questions.question: Which inventory method values ending inventory based on the most recent purchase cost?
questions.explanation: LIFO assumes the last purchased items are used first, so ending inventory reflects older costs.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Valuation Methods, pp. 4.60–4.65)

questions.question: Which type of demand is directly influenced by customer orders rather than forecasts?
questions.explanation: Independent demand is based on actual customer orders and forecasts for finished goods, unlike dependent demand which comes from production schedules.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand Management (Demand Types, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which production strategy builds inventory in advance of seasonal demand peaks?
questions.explanation: The level production strategy keeps production steady and uses inventory to absorb demand fluctuations, particularly during seasonal peaks.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Production Strategies, pp. 2.20–2.25)

questions.question: Which inventory management principle states that a small percentage of items often accounts for a large percentage of value?
questions.explanation: The Pareto principle (80/20 rule) is used in ABC analysis, where a small number of high-value items typically represent most of the total inventory value.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (ABC Classification, pp. 4.28–4.33)

questions.question: Which lean concept focuses on reducing setup times to allow smaller lot sizes?
questions.explanation: SMED reduces setup times, enabling smaller lot sizes, more flexibility, and reduced inventory in lean manufacturing.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Tools, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which input is required for capacity planning but not for MRP?
questions.explanation: Capacity planning requires work center availability data to assess whether planned orders can be executed with available resources.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Inputs to Capacity Planning, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which concept in project management provides a buffer to protect project completion dates?
questions.explanation: The critical chain buffer protects the project completion date against variations in task durations and resource availability.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 5 – Distribution and Logistics (Critical Chain Concepts, pp. 5.28–5.32)

questions.question: Which type of cost increases as inventory levels rise?
questions.explanation: Carrying costs, such as storage, insurance, and obsolescence, increase with higher inventory levels.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Costs, pp. 4.5–4.10)

questions.question: Which scheduling method uses visual tools to display operations against time?
questions.explanation: Gantt charts graphically display operations or tasks over time, commonly used for scheduling and progress tracking.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Scheduling Tools, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which replenishment approach ensures suppliers deliver materials exactly when needed for production?
questions.explanation: JIT aims to receive materials exactly when needed, minimizing inventory and waste while improving flow.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (JIT, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which planning tool links long-term strategy with day-to-day operations?
questions.explanation: S&OP serves as the bridge between strategic plans and operational execution, aligning supply, demand, and financial objectives.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Strategic Alignment, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which document communicates the quantities and timing of end items to be produced?
questions.explanation: The Master Production Schedule (MPS) defines what end items will be produced, in what quantities, and when they will be delivered.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (MPS, pp. 2.25–2.30)

questions.question: Which type of inventory is held to protect against uncertainty in demand or supply?
questions.explanation: Safety stock is held as a buffer against variability in demand or lead time to prevent stockouts.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Types of Inventory, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which system focuses on managing the flow of materials from suppliers through to customers?
questions.explanation: Supply Chain Management (SCM) integrates suppliers, manufacturers, warehouses, and customers to ensure smooth flow of materials and information.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Supply Chain Overview (SCM, pp. 1.5–1.10)

questions.question: Which metric is used to measure how effectively inventory is being utilized?
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover measures how many times inventory is sold and replaced over a period, indicating efficiency in inventory use.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Performance Measures, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which forecasting technique relies on historical data without considering external factors?
questions.explanation: Time series forecasting uses historical demand patterns such as trend and seasonality to predict future demand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Forecasting Methods, pp. 2.25–2.30)

questions.question: Which strategy delays final product assembly until customer orders are received?
questions.explanation: Assemble-to-order keeps components ready and final assembly is done only after customer orders are received, balancing responsiveness and efficiency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Production Environments, pp. 3.15–3.20)

questions.question: Which scheduling rule gives priority to jobs with the least amount of time remaining until due date?
questions.explanation: The earliest due date rule prioritizes jobs with the soonest due dates, reducing lateness and missed deadlines.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Dispatching Rules, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which type of bill of material shows all components needed across multiple products?
questions.explanation: A super BOM includes all possible components and options for multiple product configurations, useful in assemble-to-order environments.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – MRP (Types of BOM, pp. 1.15–1.20)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing technique always orders just enough to cover requirements for a specific period?
questions.explanation: Lot-for-lot ordering exactly matches order quantities to net requirements for each period, minimizing inventory but increasing order frequency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – MRP (Lot Sizing Methods, pp. 1.30–1.35)

questions.question: Which measure indicates the ability of a system to deliver customer orders when promised?
questions.explanation: On-time delivery is a key performance measure of customer service, showing the percentage of orders delivered as promised.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Supply Chain Overview (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 1.25–1.30)

questions.question: Which capacity planning tool evaluates critical resources like labor and machines against the Master Production Schedule?
questions.explanation: Rough-Cut Capacity Planning ensures that key resources can support the MPS before committing to production.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Capacity Planning, pp. 2.40–2.45)

questions.question: Which production layout groups similar processes together, such as all drilling machines in one area?
questions.explanation: A process layout arranges resources by function, improving flexibility for varied product types.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Manufacturing Layouts, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which type of inventory is created when production exceeds immediate customer demand?
questions.explanation: Cycle stock results from production or purchasing in lot sizes larger than immediate demand requirements.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Categories, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which continuous improvement method focuses on reducing variation and defects to near zero?
questions.explanation: Six Sigma emphasizes statistical tools to reduce process variation and achieve high quality.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Six Sigma, pp. 4.20–4.25)

questions.question: Which scheduling approach uses finite capacity and adjusts for resource constraints in real time?
questions.explanation: Finite loading respects actual resource limits, ensuring schedules are feasible with available capacity.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Loading Methods, pp. 3.15–3.20)

questions.question: Which type of demand comes directly from customer orders?
questions.explanation: Independent demand is not tied to any other product and comes directly from customer requirements.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Demand Types, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which inventory accuracy measure compares recorded balances with physical counts?
questions.explanation: Cycle counting is a method of auditing inventory continuously by comparing physical counts with system records.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Accuracy, pp. 4.50–4.55)

questions.question: Which supply chain strategy involves sharing demand forecasts and inventory data with suppliers?
questions.explanation: VMI shifts responsibility for replenishment to suppliers, using shared demand and inventory information.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Supply Chain Collaboration, pp. 2.50–2.55)

questions.question: Which type of order policy maintains a fixed interval between replenishments?
questions.explanation: The periodic review system places orders at regular intervals, adjusting quantity based on actual demand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Replenishment Policies, pp. 4.25–4.30)

questions.question: Which performance measure calculates the percentage of time a machine is actually producing versus available time?
questions.explanation: Machine utilization measures the actual productive time relative to the machine's available time.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Performance Metrics, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which strategy delays final product differentiation until customer demand is known?
questions.explanation: Postponement delays product customization until customer orders arrive, reducing inventory risk.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Postponement Strategy, pp. 2.55–2.60)

questions.question: Which term refers to the longest sequence of dependent activities in a project schedule?
questions.explanation: The critical path is the longest set of dependent tasks that determines the shortest project completion time.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Project Scheduling, pp. 3.25–3.30)

questions.question: Which measure evaluates how frequently inventory is sold and replaced over a period?
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover measures efficiency by dividing cost of goods sold by average inventory.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Performance Metrics, pp. 4.60–4.65)

questions.question: Which capacity strategy adds resources only when demand exceeds current capability?
questions.explanation: Lag strategy waits until demand is proven before adding capacity, minimizing risk of overcapacity.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Capacity Strategies, pp. 2.35–2.40)

questions.question: Which system uses visual signals like cards to authorize material movement or production?
questions.explanation: Kanban is a visual pull system that signals when to move or produce items.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Lean and Kanban, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which cost includes expenses like storage, insurance, obsolescence, and capital tied up in inventory?
questions.explanation: Carrying costs represent the expenses of holding inventory, including space, handling, and risk.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Costs, pp. 4.20–4.25)

questions.question: Which sourcing strategy uses a single supplier to gain economies of scale?
questions.explanation: Single sourcing allows stronger supplier relationships and lower costs but increases supply risk.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – Strategy (Sourcing Approaches, pp. 1.40–1.45)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing rule orders the exact net requirements for each period?
questions.explanation: Lot-for-lot minimizes inventory by ordering only what is needed each period.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Lot Sizing, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which type of production system produces high-volume, standardized products with low flexibility?
questions.explanation: Continuous production runs 24/7 with minimal variation, such as in chemicals or oil refining.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Production Systems, pp. 3.20–3.25)

questions.question: Which performance metric measures how often customer orders are delivered on time and in full?
questions.explanation: Perfect order fulfillment tracks orders delivered on time, complete, damage-free, and with correct documentation.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – Strategy (Performance Metrics, pp. 1.60–1.65)

questions.question: Which approach to quality emphasizes designing processes to prevent defects rather than inspecting finished goods?
questions.explanation: Quality at the source requires employees to take responsibility for producing defect-free work, preventing errors early.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Quality Approaches, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which method balances material flow through constraints by scheduling work at the pace of the slowest resource?
questions.explanation: Drum-buffer-rope schedules the system to the constraint’s pace, protecting flow with time buffers.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Theory of Constraints, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which forecast error measure expresses error as a percentage of actual demand?
questions.explanation: MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error) allows error comparison across different scales by using percentages.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Forecast Performance, pp. 2.35–2.40)

questions.question: Which production environment starts work only after receiving a customer order?
questions.explanation: Make-to-order reduces finished goods inventory by producing only after an order is confirmed.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Manufacturing Environments, pp. 3.15–3.20)

questions.question: Which term refers to the difference between available supply and forecasted demand in a master production schedule?
questions.explanation: Available-to-promise (ATP) represents the uncommitted portion of inventory or planned production available for customer orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (ATP, pp. 2.45–2.50)

questions.question: Which replenishment system issues orders at fixed time intervals regardless of demand?
questions.explanation: Periodic review replenishes inventory at set intervals, adjusting order quantities to restore target levels.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Replenishment Methods, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which process continuously compares actual performance with planned performance to ensure alignment?
questions.explanation: Closed-loop control provides feedback to adjust operations so they stay aligned with plans.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Supply Chain Overview (Control Systems, pp. 1.35–1.40)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing technique groups requirements into weekly buckets to reduce order frequency?
questions.explanation: Period order quantity accumulates requirements for a set number of periods, balancing ordering and holding costs.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Lot Sizing Methods, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which scheduling method prioritizes jobs based on the shortest processing time?
questions.explanation: Shortest processing time reduces average job flow time and increases throughput efficiency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Dispatching Rules, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which planning horizon defines the short-term period where changes to the master schedule are highly restricted?
questions.explanation: The frozen zone limits changes in the near term to protect material and capacity commitments.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Time Fences, pp. 2.50–2.55)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of reverse logistics?

options.a: Managing the flow of goods from suppliers to manufacturers
options.b: Coordinating the return of products, recycling, and disposal

questions.explanation: Reverse logistics focuses on managing returns, recycling, remanufacturing, and proper disposal of products in the supply chain.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section D: Reverse Logistics, pp. 355–359)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of a push-based supply chain?

options.b: Relies on forecasts to drive production and distribution
options.c: Focuses on rapid response to market changes

questions.explanation: Push-based supply chains use forecasts to determine production and distribution, which can lead to excess inventory if forecasts are inaccurate.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section C: Push vs. Pull Strategies, pp. 65–68)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key advantage of vertical integration?

options.a: Reduced dependency on suppliers and greater control

questions.explanation: Vertical integration provides more control over supply chain processes by reducing reliance on external suppliers.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section B: Make vs. Buy Decisions, pp. 135–138)

questions.question: Which of the following best defines supply chain visibility?

options.a: The ability to monitor supply chain processes in real time
options.b: The number of warehouses in a network
options.c: The ability to reduce safety stock

questions.explanation: Supply chain visibility enables organizations to track goods, materials, and information in real time across the supply chain.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Visibility and Transparency, pp. 340–343)

questions.question: Which type of trade-off is most commonly addressed in supply chain design?
questions.explanation: Supply chain design often requires balancing cost efficiency with service level performance to meet customer expectations.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section A: Trade-offs in Design, pp. 125–128)

questions.question: Which process focuses on identifying suppliers, developing contracts, and maintaining supplier relationships?
questions.explanation: Procurement manages the sourcing process, supplier selection, contracting, and ongoing supplier relationship management.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section D: Procurement and Supplier Management, pp. 170–174)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes capacity planning?

options.a: Ensuring that supply chain resources match demand requirements

questions.explanation: Capacity planning ensures that resources such as facilities, equipment, and labor are aligned with demand.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section E: Capacity Management, pp. 270–273)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes vendor-managed inventory (VMI)?

options.a: Suppliers manage replenishment of inventory at the customer’s location
options.d: Inventory is tracked by financial auditors

questions.explanation: In VMI, the supplier takes responsibility for maintaining inventory levels at the customer’s location.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section B: Inventory Collaboration, pp. 230–233)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key driver of supply chain complexity?
questions.explanation: Global sourcing and distribution increase complexity due to longer lead times, cultural differences, and regulatory requirements.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section D: Global Supply Chains, pp. 72–75)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of just-in-time (JIT) systems?
questions.explanation: JIT systems focus on reducing waste by producing goods only in response to actual customer demand.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section F: Lean and JIT, pp. 280–283)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key role of third-party logistics (3PL) providers?

options.b: Providing specialized logistics services such as warehousing and transportation

questions.explanation: 3PL providers offer specialized logistics services, including transportation, warehousing, and sometimes value-added services.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section E: Outsourcing Logistics, pp. 180–183)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key benefit of collaborative planning, forecasting, and replenishment (CPFR)?

options.b: Improved forecast accuracy through data sharing

questions.explanation: CPFR enhances forecast accuracy by enabling partners to share information and jointly plan demand and replenishment.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section C: CPFR, pp. 240–243)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a responsive supply chain?

options.b: Prioritizes speed and flexibility to meet customer needs

questions.explanation: Responsive supply chains prioritize speed, agility, and flexibility to adapt quickly to changes in customer demand.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section C: Responsive vs. Efficient Models, pp. 60–64)

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary purpose of performance metrics in supply chain management?

options.b: To align operational activities with strategic objectives

questions.explanation: Performance metrics ensure that supply chain operations are aligned with business strategy and customer service goals.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section C: Supply Chain Metrics, pp. 160–163)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes supply chain sustainability?

options.b: Balancing environmental, social, and economic goals in supply chain decisions

questions.explanation: Supply chain sustainability integrates environmental and social responsibility with economic performance.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section E: Sustainability, pp. 365–369)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key objective of supply chain design?

options.c: Balancing cost, quality, and service across the supply chain

questions.explanation: Supply chain design seeks to create a structure that delivers optimal service levels at the lowest total cost, while maintaining quality.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section A: Supply Chain Design Fundamentals, pp. 120–123)

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a supply chain strategy?

options.a: A set of software tools used to monitor logistics
options.b: A plan for aligning supply chain activities with business goals

questions.explanation: A supply chain strategy defines how a company will align its supply chain to support business objectives, such as cost leadership, responsiveness, or innovation.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section B: Aligning Supply Chain with Business Strategy, pp. 45–49)

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary purpose of Sales and Operations Planning (S&OP)?

options.b: To balance demand and supply at the aggregate level

questions.explanation: S&OP ensures alignment between demand and supply by creating a consensus-based plan that balances resources with customer needs.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section A: Sales and Operations Planning, pp. 210–214)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key benefit of global supply chains?

options.c: Access to broader markets and resources

questions.explanation: Global supply chains allow organizations to access wider markets and tap into global resources, though often at the cost of increased complexity.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section D: Global Supply Chains, pp. 72–75)

questions.question: In lean supply chain management, which of the following is emphasized?

options.b: Maintaining high levels of safety stock

questions.explanation: Lean supply chain management focuses on identifying and eliminating waste in processes to improve efficiency and reduce cost.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section A: Lean Principles, pp. 315–318)

questions.question: Which of the following tools is most commonly used for demand forecasting?
questions.explanation: CPFR is a collaborative forecasting process that enables partners to share data and create more accurate demand forecasts.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section C: Demand Management, pp. 240–243)

questions.question: Which metric best measures supply chain responsiveness?
questions.explanation: Order fulfillment lead time reflects how quickly a supply chain can respond to customer orders.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section C: Performance Metrics, pp. 160–163)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the bullwhip effect?

options.a: Increased customer churn due to poor service
options.b: Amplification of demand variability up the supply chain
options.c: A strategy to minimize transportation cost
options.d: Use of safety stock to protect against shortages

questions.explanation: The bullwhip effect occurs when small fluctuations in customer demand cause larger swings in demand at upstream stages of the supply chain.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section D: Demand Variability and Bullwhip Effect, pp. 260–262)

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary role of distribution centers?

options.c: Consolidating and dispersing inventory for efficient delivery

questions.explanation: Distribution centers serve as hubs for consolidating inventory and dispersing it closer to customers for faster and cost-effective fulfillment.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section E: Distribution Network Design, pp. 185–188)

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary purpose of inventory in a supply chain?

options.b: To serve as a buffer against uncertainty

questions.explanation: Inventory is held in a supply chain primarily as a buffer against demand and supply uncertainty.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section B: Inventory Management, pp. 225–227)

questions.question: Which technology enables real-time visibility in supply chain operations?
questions.explanation: RFID technology allows for real-time tracking and visibility of goods throughout the supply chain.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Supply Chain Visibility, pp. 340–343)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes postponement in supply chain design?

options.b: Delaying product differentiation until closer to the customer
options.d: Delaying quality inspections until after production

questions.explanation: Postponement delays final product differentiation or customization until demand is known, reducing inventory and increasing flexibility.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section F: Postponement Strategies, pp. 190–193)

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary purpose of supply chain risk management?

options.a: Eliminating all risks from the supply chain

questions.explanation: Supply chain risk management involves identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks that could disrupt supply chain performance.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section B: Risk Management, pp. 325–329)

questions.question: Which type of supply chain strategy is most appropriate for innovative products with unpredictable demand?
questions.explanation: Agile supply chains are best suited for innovative products with uncertain demand, as they emphasize flexibility and responsiveness.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section C: Supply Chain Models, pp. 60–64)

questions.question: Which financial metric is most directly affected by supply chain efficiency?
questions.explanation: Efficient supply chain operations improve asset utilization, which directly enhances return on assets (ROA).
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section C: Financial Metrics, pp. 150–153)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of Sales and Operations Execution (S&OE)?

options.b: Daily and weekly alignment of supply and demand

questions.explanation: S&OE focuses on short-term execution, ensuring daily and weekly alignment of demand and supply plans.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section A: S&OP and S&OE, pp. 215–218)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of supply chain segmentation?

options.a: Dividing suppliers into categories by geography
options.b: Customizing supply chain strategies based on product and customer characteristics
options.c: Segmenting demand into forecasted and actual categories
options.d: Separating logistics into inbound and outbound flows

questions.explanation: Supply chain segmentation allows organizations to apply different strategies for different products, markets, and customers.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section E: Segmentation, pp. 80–83)

questions.question: Which inventory management approach is designed to minimize waste and synchronize supply with demand?
questions.explanation: Kanban is a visual scheduling system that helps minimize waste and align production with actual demand.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section F: Lean and JIT, pp. 280–283)

questions.question: Which type of outsourcing relationship involves a long-term, collaborative partnership between a buyer and a supplier?
questions.explanation: Strategic outsourcing establishes long-term, collaborative partnerships to achieve shared goals.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section D: Outsourcing and Supplier Management, pp. 170–175)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key benefit of blockchain in supply chain management?
questions.explanation: Blockchain provides secure, transparent, and immutable records, improving traceability and trust across the supply chain.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Digital Supply Chains, pp. 345–348)

questions.question: Which forecasting technique uses past demand data to predict future demand patterns?
questions.explanation: Time series analysis uses historical data trends and patterns to forecast future demand.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section C: Forecasting Methods, pp. 235–238)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a supply chain control tower?

options.b: A centralized hub for real-time visibility and analytics

questions.explanation: A control tower provides centralized, real-time visibility and analytics to improve decision-making.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Visibility and Analytics, pp. 341–345)

questions.question: Which type of supplier relationship emphasizes innovation and joint development?
questions.explanation: Collaborative supplier relationships focus on innovation, shared goals, and long-term partnerships.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section D: Supplier Relationship Management, pp. 170–174)

questions.question: Which type of inventory is held to decouple operations and ensure smooth flow between processes?
questions.explanation: Decoupling inventory ensures continuity of operations by buffering variability between processes.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section B: Inventory Types, pp. 226–229)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key benefit of postponement strategies?
questions.explanation: Postponement increases customization flexibility by delaying final product differentiation.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section F: Postponement Strategies, pp. 190–193)

questions.question: Which strategy focuses on maintaining low costs while serving stable and predictable markets?
questions.explanation: Efficient supply chains focus on cost efficiency and are best suited for stable, predictable demand.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Strategy (Section C: Supply Chain Models, pp. 60–63)

questions.question: Which financial measure indicates the time it takes for a company to convert investments into cash flow?
questions.explanation: Cash-to-cash cycle time measures how quickly investments in inventory are converted into customer cash receipts.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section C: Financial Metrics, pp. 150–153)

questions.question: Which type of logistics network is designed to minimize transportation cost by shipping in full truckloads?
questions.explanation: Direct shipment moves goods from supplier to customer without intermediate handling, minimizing costs when full truckloads are feasible.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section E: Distribution Strategies, pp. 185–188)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes resilience in supply chains?

options.a: The ability to reduce production lead times
options.b: The ability to anticipate, respond, and recover from disruptions
options.c: The ability to eliminate all risks
options.d: The ability to lower transportation costs

questions.explanation: Resilience refers to a supply chain's ability to anticipate, absorb, and recover from disruptions effectively.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section B: Risk Management, pp. 326–329)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key enabler of supply chain collaboration?
questions.explanation: Standardized data sharing across partners is a key enabler of collaboration and alignment in supply chains.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section C: Collaboration, pp. 240–244)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes demand shaping?

options.a: Adjusting demand patterns through pricing and promotions
options.b: Forecasting future demand using time series data

questions.explanation: Demand shaping influences customer demand using pricing, promotions, and marketing campaigns.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section D: Demand Management, pp. 258–262)

questions.question: Which technology provides predictive insights to optimize supply chain performance?
questions.explanation: Artificial intelligence enhances forecasting, planning, and optimization by providing predictive insights.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Digital Supply Chains, pp. 345–348)

questions.question: Which type of inventory is built up in anticipation of seasonal peaks in demand?
questions.explanation: Anticipation inventory is accumulated in advance of expected seasonal or promotional demand peaks.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section B: Inventory Types, pp. 226–229)

questions.question: Which sourcing strategy spreads risk by using multiple suppliers for a single component?
questions.explanation: Dual sourcing balances risk and flexibility by engaging multiple suppliers for the same component.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section D: Sourcing Strategies, pp. 170–174)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of a supply chain network design tool?

options.b: To optimize facility locations, flows, and costs

questions.explanation: Network design tools are used to evaluate facility locations, transportation routes, and cost trade-offs in supply chain structures.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section A: Network Design Tools, pp. 120–123)

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary objective of supply chain benchmarking?

options.b: To compare performance against best-in-class standards

questions.explanation: Benchmarking helps organizations measure performance against industry leaders and identify areas for improvement.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section A: Benchmarking, pp. 310–314)

questions.question: Which of the following technologies is most closely associated with end-to-end supply chain connectivity?
questions.explanation: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems integrate data across supply chain functions, enabling end-to-end connectivity.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section G: Enterprise Systems, pp. 285–289)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of life-cycle assessment (LCA) in supply chains?

options.b: To evaluate environmental impact from production to disposal

questions.explanation: Life-cycle assessment examines environmental impacts at every stage of a product’s life cycle, from raw materials to disposal.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section E: Sustainability, pp. 365–369)

questions.question: Which inventory control method sets limits on the minimum and maximum stock levels to guide replenishment decisions?
questions.explanation: A min-max system establishes upper and lower limits for inventory levels and triggers replenishment when the minimum threshold is reached.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section B: Inventory Control Methods, pp. 228–231)

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary advantage of nearshoring compared to offshoring?

options.a: Lower transportation cost and shorter lead times
options.c: Access to a broader labor pool

questions.explanation: Nearshoring moves production closer to demand markets, reducing lead times and transportation costs.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section B: Location Decisions, pp. 140–144)

questions.question: Which supply chain practice involves aligning incentives and sharing risks among partners?
questions.explanation: Collaborative risk-sharing agreements encourage trust and performance by distributing risks and rewards fairly among partners.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section B: Risk Management, pp. 328–330)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the function of advanced planning and scheduling (APS) systems?

options.b: To integrate and optimize production, distribution, and demand planning

questions.explanation: APS systems extend ERP by providing advanced optimization capabilities across production, distribution, and demand planning.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section G: Advanced Planning Systems, pp. 289–292)

questions.question: Which of the following strategies helps reduce the impact of demand variability by pooling risk across markets?
questions.explanation: Risk pooling reduces variability by aggregating demand across multiple products, locations, or markets.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section A: Risk Pooling, pp. 126–129)

questions.question: Which of the following best defines total landed cost in supply chain management?

options.a: The total cost of raw materials only
options.b: The cost of manufacturing plus labor
options.c: The sum of purchase price, transportation, duties, taxes, and handling
options.d: The financial metric used in life-cycle costing

questions.explanation: Total landed cost includes all costs associated with acquiring a product, including purchase, transportation, tariffs, and handling.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section B: Cost Analysis, pp. 145–148)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of supply chain orchestration?

options.a: Balancing labor costs across multiple plants
options.b: Coordinating activities and data across diverse supply chain partners in real time

questions.explanation: Supply chain orchestration refers to the synchronization of activities, processes, and data across multiple stakeholders to achieve seamless execution.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Orchestration and Control, pp. 344–347)

questions.question: Which sourcing strategy focuses on building long-term partnerships with fewer, carefully selected suppliers?
questions.explanation: Supplier rationalization reduces the number of suppliers while strengthening strategic relationships with those retained.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section D: Supplier Management, pp. 171–174)

questions.question: Which of the following is a major benefit of digital twins in supply chain management?

options.b: Simulating supply chain scenarios for optimization

questions.explanation: Digital twins allow supply chain managers to run simulations, test scenarios, and predict outcomes to improve decision-making.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Digital Supply Chains, pp. 346–349)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a green supply chain initiative?

options.b: Implementing eco-friendly practices in sourcing, production, and logistics

questions.explanation: Green supply chain initiatives focus on sustainability, reducing environmental impact, and improving resource efficiency.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section E: Sustainability, pp. 366–369)

questions.question: Which of the following is a key purpose of sales and operations execution (S&OE) compared to S&OP?

options.b: Weekly adjustments to align supply and demand in the short term

questions.explanation: S&OE ensures tactical adjustments in daily and weekly horizons to keep supply and demand aligned in the short term.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section A: S&OE, pp. 216–218)

questions.question: Which strategy reduces transportation cost and lead time by bypassing distribution centers?
questions.explanation: Direct shipping moves goods straight from supplier to customer without intermediate storage or handling.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section E: Distribution Strategies, pp. 186–188)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes mass customization in supply chain strategy?

options.b: Customizing products at low cost using modular design and flexible processes
options.c: Eliminating all inventory to reduce costs
options.d: Using only local suppliers to customize offerings

questions.explanation: Mass customization combines efficiency of mass production with flexibility to offer tailored products through modular designs.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section F: Postponement and Customization, pp. 191–193)

questions.question: Which financial measure best evaluates supply chain liquidity?
questions.explanation: Cash-to-cash cycle time measures liquidity by indicating how quickly investments in inventory are converted into cash.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section C: Financial Metrics, pp. 150–153)

questions.question: Which of the following practices helps improve order accuracy and reduce picking errors in warehouses?
questions.explanation: Voice-directed picking systems guide warehouse workers through tasks, improving accuracy and efficiency in order fulfillment.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section H: Warehouse Management, pp. 295–298)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes demand-driven material requirements planning (DDMRP)?

options.a: Planning based solely on long-term forecasts
options.b: Using real-time demand signals and inventory buffers to plan supply
options.c: Eliminating all forms of safety stock
options.d: Planning only at the strategic level

questions.explanation: DDMRP combines demand signals with strategically placed inventory buffers to improve responsiveness and reduce variability.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section D: Demand Management and DDMRP, pp. 258–263)

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary goal of collaborative planning, forecasting, and replenishment (CPFR)?

options.b: To align forecasts and replenishment plans between supply chain partners
options.c: To reduce supplier lead times to zero

questions.explanation: CPFR enables trading partners to share forecasts, demand data, and replenishment plans, improving visibility and alignment.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section B: Collaboration, pp. 225–229)

questions.question: Which type of risk management strategy involves transferring financial risk exposure to a third party?
questions.explanation: Risk transfer, such as insurance or outsourcing, shifts the impact of risks to another party.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section F: Risk Management, pp. 374–377)

questions.question: Which of the following is the best example of postponement in supply chain strategy?

options.a: Producing finished goods only after customer orders are received
options.b: Standardizing parts but delaying final product differentiation until later in the process
options.d: Shipping directly from supplier to customer

questions.explanation: Postponement delays final product customization until closer to customer demand, reducing inventory risk.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section F: Postponement, pp. 191–193)

questions.question: Which of the following is a benefit of nearshoring compared to offshoring?

options.a: Lower transportation costs and shorter lead times
options.b: Access to the lowest global labor rates

questions.explanation: Nearshoring brings production closer to the demand market, reducing transportation costs and improving responsiveness.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section B: Globalization, pp. 132–135)

questions.question: Which metric best measures supply chain responsiveness?
questions.explanation: Order cycle time measures how quickly a company can fulfill customer demand, making it a key responsiveness metric.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section C: Performance Metrics, pp. 153–155)

questions.question: Which warehouse strategy focuses on minimizing travel time for pickers by storing fast-moving items closer to dispatch areas?
questions.explanation: ABC slotting stores high-demand (A-class) items in more accessible locations to improve picking efficiency.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section H: Warehouse Operations, pp. 292–295)

questions.question: Which technology enables secure, tamper-proof sharing of supply chain transactions among multiple parties?
questions.explanation: Blockchain creates a decentralized ledger that records transactions securely and transparently across supply chain partners.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 4 – Supply Chain Improvements and Best Practices (Section C: Digital Supply Chains, pp. 348–350)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the bullwhip effect?

options.b: Amplification of demand variability as it moves upstream in the supply chain
options.c: A mismatch between transportation modes and delivery requirements
options.d: Failure of suppliers to meet quality standards

questions.explanation: The bullwhip effect occurs when small fluctuations in customer demand cause larger swings in orders up the supply chain.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 1 – Supply Chain Design and Strategy (Section C: Demand Distortion, pp. 84–87)

questions.question: Which of the following is the main benefit of vendor-managed inventory (VMI)?

options.b: Allowing suppliers to manage replenishment and improve stock availability
options.c: Eliminating the need for purchase orders
options.d: Reducing supplier lead times to zero

questions.explanation: VMI gives suppliers responsibility for monitoring and replenishing customer inventory, improving efficiency and service levels.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section B: Collaborative Relationships, pp. 228–231)

questions.question: Which of the following best describes omni-channel fulfillment?

options.a: Selling only through physical retail stores
options.c: Integrating online and offline channels to deliver a seamless customer experience
options.d: Restricting orders to a single distribution center

questions.explanation: Omni-channel fulfillment integrates e-commerce, retail, and other channels so customers can buy, receive, and return products seamlessly.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section E: Distribution Strategies, pp. 184–187)

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary advantage of a make-to-order (MTO) production strategy?
questions.explanation: MTO reduces the need for holding finished goods inventory since products are made only after orders are received.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section D: Manufacturing Strategies, pp. 172–175)

questions.question: In supplier relationship management (SRM), which of the following best describes a strategic supplier?

options.a: A supplier selected solely on lowest price
options.b: A supplier that provides non-critical indirect materials
options.c: A supplier that collaborates closely on innovation and long-term goals
options.d: A supplier used only during demand peaks

questions.explanation: Strategic suppliers are long-term partners contributing innovation, risk sharing, and competitive advantage.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section A: Supplier Segmentation, pp. 122–125)

questions.question: Which inventory management method focuses on reducing waste by receiving materials only as they are needed in production?
questions.explanation: JIT minimizes inventory levels by aligning deliveries closely with production schedules.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section D: Lean, pp. 256–259)

questions.question: Which type of distribution network uses regional warehouses to replenish local demand more quickly?
questions.explanation: Decentralized distribution positions inventory closer to customers to reduce lead times and improve service.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section E: Distribution, pp. 182–185)

questions.question: Which of the following is the main purpose of reverse logistics?

options.c: Handling product returns, recycling, and disposal

questions.explanation: Reverse logistics manages returns, refurbishments, recycling, and end-of-life product recovery.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section H: Reverse Supply Chains, pp. 202–205)

questions.question: Which of the following is the most critical input for sales and operations planning (S&OP)?
questions.explanation: Accurate demand forecasts are essential for balancing supply and demand in S&OP.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 3 – Supply Chain Planning and Execution (Section A: S&OP, pp. 214–217)

questions.question: Which performance metric is most useful in evaluating supply chain flexibility?

options.c: Ability to ramp production up or down quickly

questions.explanation: Flexibility is measured by how quickly a supply chain can adjust capacity in response to changes in demand.
questions.reference: CSCP Module 2 – Supply Chain Design (Section C: Flexibility, pp. 155–158)

questions.question: Which sustainability practice focuses on reducing the carbon footprint of logistics operations?
